name: Cameron–Erdős conjecture
rephrased: The total number of subsets of the integers from 1 to n that do not contain any three elements x, y, z (not necessarily distinct) with x + y = z grows asymptotically as a constant times 2 raised to the power of n/2.
implication_form: If a subset of {1,2,...,n} is sum-free, then the number of such subsets is asymptotically equal to c * 2^(n/2) for some constant c depending on n.
explained: The Cameron–Erdős conjecture addresses the asymptotic growth rate of the maximum number of sum-free subsets of the set {1, 2, ..., n}. A set S ⊆ {1, 2, ..., n} is sum-free if no two elements in S can be summed to give another element in S (i.e., there do not exist x, y, z ∈ S such that x + y = z). The conjecture, proposed by Cameron and Erdős in 1988, states that the maximum number of sum-free subsets is asymptotically equivalent to c * 2^(n/2) for some constant c (which depends on the parity of n). This means that, in the limit as n becomes very large, the maximum number of sum-free subsets grows like 2 raised to the power of n/2, multiplied by a constant. This conjecture was proven independently by Ben Green and Alexander Sapozhenko in 2003.
